remarks.para: Because this method returns the content object itself, it allows you to initialize a complex content tree with a single statement. For example:
remarks.code: 'Setting both background color and foreground color in 'a single statement New AcmText("some text") _ .SetProperty("Style.BackgroundColor", Color.Red) _ .SetProperty("Style.ForegroundColor", Color.Blue)

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmContent.Tag
member.summary: Gets or sets the object that contains data about the content.
member.remarks: Any type derived from the class can be assigned to this property. A common use for the property is to store context information that is closely associated with the content. For example, you can store the current chapter information (such as chapter number and name) in the property, and then later use this information to render page header and footer. See here for an example on how to use this property.

member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether this content is a block content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmContent.IsInline
member.summary: Returns a value indicating whether this content is an inline content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.Padding
member.summary: Get or set the padding values. Padding defines the extra space reserved inside a content's border around its child content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.Left
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance between a block content's left edge and the left edge of its containing block's client area.
member.remarks: Setting this property causes the block to be floated. This property is only used by a block content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.Top
member.summary: Gets or sets the distance between a block content's top edge and the top edge of its containing block's client area.
member.remarks: Setting this property causes the block to be floated. This property is only used by a block content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.Width
member.summary: Gets or sets the block width.
member.remarks: Note that a block width defines the distance between the left edge and right edge of a block's client area, which excludes padding, border and margin. This property is only used by a block content.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.Height
member.summary: Gets or sets the block height.

remarks.para: Note that a block height defines the distance between the top edge and bottom edge of a block's client area, which excludes padding, border and margin. This property is only used by a block content.
This value is suggestive only. If the actual block content height is greater than this value, then the actual content height is used.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.LineHeight
member.summary: Get or set the minimum line height.
member.remarks: If the actual line content height is smaller than this value, extra padding will be added to the top and bottom of the line. If the line content height is greater than this value, the actual line height value will be used.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.BackgroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the content's background color.
member.remarks: If this property is set, the content fills its background with the given color. The filling area includes padding and border, but excludes margin.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.ForegroundColor
member.summary: Gets or sets the content's foreground color.
member.remarks: This property is used by as text color.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.WordSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the word spacing for an object.
member.remarks: This property is only used by an object but can be applied on any parent object because it is inheritable.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.ParagraphSpacing
member.summary: Gets or sets the extra spacing to be added between paragraphs by an object.
member.remarks: This property is only used by an object but can be applied on any parent object because it is inheritable.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.OffsetX
member.summary: Gets or sets the horizontal offset from an object's final position to its original position.

remarks.para: Use this property to move a content towards left or right from its original position. For example, you can use this property to move an image towards the left or right. Setting this property moves the target object only. It does not affect any other contents or alter the output layout.
If an object is also being scaled (for example, a scaled image), this offset is being applied before scaling.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmStyle.OffsetY
member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical offset from an object's final position to its original position.
member.remarks: This property is the same as except for vertical offset.

member.remarks: This property is applied to block content only.

member.summary: Gets or sets the vertical alignment of the child contents.
member.remarks: This property is applied to block content only.

member.name: T:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable
member.summary: A block-level flow content element that provides a grid-based presentation organized by rows and columns.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.#ctor(System.Single[])
member.summary: Create a new table.
member.param: A list of float values that specifies column width.

remarks.para: Total number of columns are determined by the number of column width values. The first value specifies the width of the first column, the second value specifies the width of the second column, and so on.

Note that the column width is not the same as cell width. A cell's width excludes the cell's padding, border and margins. A column's width includes those values. Thus the total width of the table element is the same as the sum of all column widths.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.Rows
member.summary: Gets the table row collection.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.Columns
member.summary: Gets the table column collection.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.CellSpacing
member.summary: Gets or set the spacing between cells.
member.remarks: When this property is set, it overwrites each cell's margin with 1/2 of the value of this property. For example, setting this property to "1" has the same effects as setting all cells' margin to "0.5" on all sides.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.CellPadding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding for all cells.
member.remarks: When this property is set, it overwrites each cell's padding value.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.GridLineType
member.summary: Gets the table grid line type.

remarks.para: An can optionally have horizontal and vertical grid lines between rows and columns as well as a frame around the whole table. Use this property to specify whether to draw these lines.

If this property includes the option and the table's property also includes Borders, then the border will be drawn outside of the table frame. In another word, table frame and border do not interact with each other.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmTable.GridLineInfo
member.summary: Gets or sets the grid line color, style and width.
member.remarks: To enable grid lines/frames on a table, you must also set to a value other than .

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Acm.AcmText.AutoTrim
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the object should automatically trims line breaks.

remarks.para: By default, line breaks and any space around the line breaks are being automatically replaced by a single space character. This allows you to use long text with C#'s multiple line string literal syntax without worrying about the line breaks. To turn this feature off, set this property to false.

Note that you shall not confuse this feature with String's Trim function, which removes leading and trailing white-space characters. never removes leading or trailing white-space characters. It replaces line breaks and any possible white-space around the line breaks with a single space character.

member.remarks: By default, automatically replaces line breaks and any possible white-space around the line break with a single space character. This allows you to write long text using C#'s multiple line string literal syntax without worrying about the line breaks. You can turn this feature off by setting to false.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.Contents.PdfContent.SaveGfxState
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the object should automatically save and restore graphic state when rendered.

remarks.para: This property is set to true by default, in which case any graphic state changes occured inside this PdfContent would not have any impact on anything outside of the PdfContent object.
If this property is set to false, then graphic state is not restored after the PdfContent is rendered. Consider the following scenario:

list.item: PdfContent A contains PdfContent B and PdfContent C;
PdfContent B's SaveGfxState is set to false;

member.name: T:EO.Pdf.PdfDestFitMode
member.summary: Specifies auto fit mode for a object.

summary.para: Does not try to automatically fit the page.
This option displays the page with the coordinates (.Location) positioned at the upper-left corner of the window and the contents of the page magnified by the .
Neither nor is used for this value.
Automatically fits the entire width of the page.

This option displays the page with the vertical coordinate top (.Top) positioned at the top edge of the window and the contents of the page magnified just enough to fit the entire width of the page within the window.
Automatically fits the entire height of the page.

This option displays the page with the horizontal coordinate left (.Left) positioned at the left edge of the window and the contents of the page magnified just enough to fit the entire height of the page within the window.
Automatically fits to the specified rectangle.

This option displays the page with its contents magnified just enough to fit the rectangle specified () entirely within the window both horizontally and vertically. If the required horizontal and vertical magnification factors are different, use the smaller of the two, centering the rectangle within the window in the other dimension.
Similar to , but uses the page's bounding box instead of .
Automatically fits the entire bounding box width of the page.
Similar to , but uses the page's bounding box instead of .
Automatically fits the entire bounding box height of the page.
Similar to , but uses the page's bounding box instead of .

member.summary: Gets or sets the auto-fit rectangle.

remarks.para: Different values interpret this rectangle differently. See for more details.

Values in this rectangle are expressed in PDF user space unit. By default, one inch is 72 user space unit. Also the Y axis grows from the bottom to top. So for example, if the paper height is 11 inch and the top margin is 1 inch, then the top of the first line on the page would have a Y value of 720 (72 * 10 inch).

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlElement.CreateLink
member.summary: Creates a object based on this element.

remarks.para: This function creates a object based on whether this element is a HTML anchor element:

list.item: For a HTML anchor element that points to another Url, the new 's will be initialized;
For a HTML anchor element that points to another anchor point inside the same document, the new 's will be initialized;
If the element is not a HTML anchor element, then neither nor will be initialized;

remarks.para: In all cases, the 's is initialized based on the element's .
Note: This function only creates the object. It does not add the link into the document. You can add the link to the document by calling method on the returned object.

member.name: T:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfSession
member.summary: Simulates a Web session that involves multiple pages.

remarks.para: Note: Each object is associated with the thread in which it is created and can only be used in that thread. Calling any methods from a different thread other than the one that creates the object will throw an exception.

member.summary: Creates a new object.

member.summary: Creates a new object using the specified object.

is an expensive object. Call to dispose the returned object as soon as the object is no longer needed.

member.summary: Close the object and release all associated resources.
member.remarks: Call this method as soon as you no longer need the object.

member.summary: Loads a Url into the session.

member.summary: Loads HTML into the session.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfSession.RunWebViewCallback(EO.WebBrowser.WebViewCallback,System.Object)
member.summary: Run a delegate in the context of this session.
member.param: Additional arguments to be passed to your delegate.

remarks.para: Internally EO.Pdf use a object to load the page and perform the conversion. You can use this method to interact with this underlying object directly. For example, you can load a page and then execute certain JavaScript in and then perform a conversion. The following code demonstrates how to use this feature:
remarks.code:
'WebView and other related classes are defined in EO.WebBrowser 'namespace. Also make sure EO.WebBrowser.dll is referenced by 'your project Imports EO.WebBrowser
Using session As HtmlToPdfSession = HtmlToPdfSession.Create() 'Run a callback in the session to load a special request session.RunWebViewCallback( _ Function(webView As WebView, args As Object) 'Create a EO.WebBrowser.Request object Dim request As New Request(your_special_url)
'Add some additional header entries request.Headers.Add(your_special_header_name, your_special_header_value)
'Load the request webView.LoadRequestAndWait(request)
Return Nothing
End Function, _ Nothing)
'Perform the conversion session.RenderAsPDF(result_pdf_file) End Using
remarks.para: This method can not be used when is called since the classic engine does not use to perform the conversion.

member.returns: Returns the value returned by the callback.

member.remarks: This method submit the page as if user has clicked the submit button.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfSession.Submit(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Submit the current page to the specified Url.
member.param: The target Url. Pass null (Visual Basic Nothing) to post back to the current Url.
The name of the submit button.
member.remarks: This method allows you to submit the page to a different Url than the page Url.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfSession.Submit(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Submit the current page.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfSession.GetCookies
member.summary: Gets the current cookie collections.

remarks.para: One of the primary purpose of the class is to simulate an interactive session (such as user log in) in order to get the result cookies. For example, the following code simulate a log in and then get the user's authentication cookies:
remarks.code:
'Create a new HtmlToPdfSession object Using session As HtmlToPdfSession = HtmlToPdfSession.Create()
'Load the login page session.Load("http://www.yoursite.com/Login.html")
'Fill in the "username" and "password" form fields session.Fill("username", "test1234") session.Fill("password", "abcxyz")
'Submit the page back to the server. If the login is 'successful, this reloads the page with the newly issued 'authentication cookies session.Submit()
'Get all the cookies and pass these cookies to the HTML 'to PDF converter HtmlToPdf.Options.Cookies = session.GetCookies() End Using
'Call the HTML to PDF converter to convert a page. Since 'the HTML to PDF converter has the cookies, it would 'function as it has already logged in HtmlToPdf.ConvertUrl("http://www.yoursite.com/OrderHistory.html", "orders.pdf")
remarks.para: Note that you only need to use this method if you wish to keep the cookies and use them later. If you just need to convert the page right away, you can load that page directly into the object and call to convert the page immediately. See using HtmlToPdfSession for more details.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.ColumnCount
member.summary: Specifies how many columns per page.
member.remarks: By default, the HTML to PDF converter outputs a single column on every page. Set this property to enable multiple column output.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.ColumnGapWidth
member.summary: Specifies the width of the gap between columns in inches.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.MinLoadWaitTime
member.summary: Specifies the minimum wait time in milliseconds to load a page.

remarks.para: Some web pages dynamically creates content with script. In order to capture an output that is as accurate as how the page would look to the end user, the converter waits for a short period of time before trying to render the PDF output after it has finished loading. This gap gives the page some time to execute its intialization script. Use this parameter to control the number of milliseconds the converter waits before trying to render the page.
The default value is 0, which instructs the converter to automatically use an appropriate value. To minimize the wait time, set this parameter to a very small vlaue (for example, 1 millisecond).

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.MaxLoadWaitTime
member.summary: Specifies the maximum wait time in milliseconds to load a page.

remarks.para: Before the HTML page can be rendered, it must be loaded. This can take some time, especially if the page is being loaded from a remote server. This parameter controls the number of milliseconds the converter waits before it proceed to render the page anyway.
The default value is 0, which instructs the converter to automatically use an appropriate value.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.ZoomLevel
member.summary: Gets or sets the initial zooming level.

remarks.para: Sets the initial zoom level applied during the conversion. For example, you can set ZoomLevel to 0.5 (50%) in order to fit a 10 inches wide HTML page on a 5 inches wide paper.

Note that this value sets the initial zoom level only. During the conversion the converter may choose to apply a zoom level that is lower than this value if the HTML contents is too wide to fit on the PDF page even at this initial zoom level. Because of this, value specified by this property is in fact the maximum zoom level. To instruct the converter to use exactly this zoom level with no further auto-zooming, set both and to None.
This property is automatically cleared after each conversion.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AutoFitWidth
member.summary: Specifies whether to automatically shrink the HTML page to fit the PDF page width. The default value is true.

remarks.para: This property has been deprecated. Please use instead. Setting this property to true is equivalent to setting to .

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AutoFitX
member.summary: Specifies the horizontal auto fit mode.

remarks.para: The HTML to PDF converter considers both and to decide a single final scale factor, which applies horizontally and vertically. For example, if both and are set to and,

list.item: The HTML page is twice as wide as the PDF output area;
The HTML page height is only half of the PDF output area;

remarks.para: Then the final scale factor will be 0.5 so that the whole HTML page is shrunk to half of its original size by 50% on both horizontally and vertically.
This property is automatically reset to after every conversion.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AutoFitY
member.summary: Specifies the vertical auto fit mode.

remarks.para: and are both considered together during the conversion. See remarks for for more details.
This property is automatically reset to after every conversion.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AutoBookmark

remarks.para: This property is automatically reset to the default (false) after each conversion.

remarks.para: The format string can include HTML markups as well as variables that will be replaced at runtime with the value of the variable. A variable is marked by a pair of "{" and "}". The following variables are supported:
For example, the following HeaderFormat displays current page number at the center:
remarks.code: {page_number}
remarks.para: This property is automatically cleared after each conversion.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.StartPageIndex
member.summary: Gets or set the starting page index.

remarks.para: By default, a new conversion automatically starts a new page while rendering to a object. Set this property to a non-negative value to instruct the converter to start from the specified page.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.StartPosition
member.summary: Gets or sets the starting Y offset in inches on the first page.

remarks.para: The initial value for this property is 0, which means a new conversion always starts at the top of the page. Setting this value to a positive value instructs the converter to start from the middle of the page instead of from the top. For example, setting StartPosition to 1 would start output at 1 inch below the top boundary of (if the page has a top margin of 1 inch, then the start position is 2 inches from the top edge of the paper).

You can use this property together with HtmlToPdfResult.LastPageIndex and HtmlToPdfResult.LastPosition to render multiple HTML page/snippets continuously. For example, the following code would render "paragraph2" immediately after "paragrah1" on the same page as if they were rendered with a single call.
remarks.code:
'Render some text EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfResult result = _ EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.ConverHtml("

paragraph1

", doc) 'Follow the previous output immediately EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.Options.StartPageIndex = result.LastPageIndex EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.Options.StartPosition = result.LastPosition 'You can also replace the above code with 'EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.Options.Follow(result) 'render some additional text. This block will follow 'the previous block immediately on the same page EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.ConverHtml("

paragraph2

", doc)

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.StartColumnIndex

remarks.para: When is set to a value greater than 0, this property and determine the start position of the output.
By default, indicates the start position of the first column of the output. Set this property to -1 to start from the on every column of the first page.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.SaveImageAsJpeg
member.summary: Specifies whether to automatically save images as JPEG.
member.remarks: The default value is true.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.JpegQualityLevel
member.summary: Specifies the JPEG compression quality level.
member.remarks: Valid values include -1 and any value ranging from 0 to 100. A quality level of 0 corresponds to the greatest compression, and a quality level of 100 corresponds to the least compression. Setting this value to -1 to use the default value.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.PreserveHighResImages
member.summary: Specifies whether to preserve high resolution images.
member.remarks:
By default, the HTML to PDF converter renders high resolution images as is to preserve the image quality. Set this property to false can reduce the final PDF file size.
This property is only used by the classic conversion engine. It is not used by the new conversion engine.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AutoAdjustForDPI
member.summary: Specifies whether to automatically adjust output based on the current system's DPI settings.
member.remarks: The default value is false.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.AllowLocalAccess
member.summary: Specifies whether to allow access to local files.

remarks.para: By default, the converter can access local files. For example, the following code would need to access local file "c:\hello.gif" in order to render the image correctly:
remarks.code: HtmlToPdf.ConvertHtml("", pdfFile);
HtmlToPdf.ConvertHtml("", pdfFile)
remarks.para: This can be a security risk if the converter is running on a server. In that case you should set this property to false. When this property is set to false, local access is still allowed if is a local path.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.TriggerMode
member.summary: Gets or sets the condition that triggers the HTML to PDF conversion.

remarks.para: The default value is , which means the HTML to PDF converter will wait for all page contents to be loaded (CSS, images, etc) before starting conversion. You can override this behavior by setting to or .
When is set to either or , you must manually trigger the conversion from JavaScript by calling the following code:
remarks.code: eoapi.convert();
remarks.para: If you do not call eoapi.convert() in your page, then the conversion will not start. It will eventually fail with a time out error.

When is set to , the converter will start immediately as soon as eoapi.convert() is called, regardless whether all page contents are loaded or not. When is set to , the converter will still wait for page contents to be loaded. The conversion will start only after page contents are loaded and eoapi.convert() is called.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.TriggerConversionManually
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether conversion should be triggered manually.
member.remarks: This property has been deprecated, use instead. The default value is false. Setting this property to true is equivalent to setting to .

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.FirstPageNumber
member.summary: Gets or sets the page number for the first page.
member.remarks: The default value is 1. This value is being used as the base number for the page_number variable in and .

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.VisibleElementIds
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of visible element Ids.

remarks.para:
Use this property to render a portion of the page instead of the full page. For example, with the following HTML file: ....header....
....main contents.....
....footer.... If you only wish to render the main contents to PDF, you can set to "contents" so that only the element whose id property is set to "contents" will be rendered (in this case a DIV element).
To specify multiple visible element Ids, use ";" to separate them. For example, "menu;contents;".

If you use ASP.NET, be aware that this property takes the client side DHTML element ID, not the ASP.NET server side control ID. Usually you can use the server control's ClientID property to get the corresponding client side DHTML element ID.
can be used together with this property to explicitly hides certain elements in the "visible" area.

member.name: P:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdfOptions.InvisibleElementIds
member.summary: Gets or sets a list of invisible element Ids.

remarks.para: Use this property to explicitly hide certain elements. For example, if you wish to hide the "Print" button in your PDF, then you can set this property to the ID of the "Print" button.
To specify multiple visible element Ids, use ";" to separate them. For example, "menu;contents;".

If you use ASP.NET, be aware that this property takes the client side DHTML element ID, not the ASP.NET server side control ID. Usually you can use the server control's ClientID property to get the corresponding client side DHTML element ID.
This property is often used together with .

member.remarks: When this property is set to true, the property of the object returned by ConvertHtml/ConvertUrl methods contains an array of page images.

remarks.para: If a table spans over multiple pages and this property is true, the HTML to PDF converter will automatically repeat thead and tfoot rows on every page. Setting this property to false to prevent such row from being repeated.
This property is automatically reset to true after every conversion.

member.name: F:EO.Pdf.SSLVerificationMode.None
member.summary: Do not verify SSL certificate against a trusted certificate authority. This allows you to use self-signed test certificate.

member.name: F:EO.Pdf.SSLVerificationMode.VerifyCertificate
member.summary: Verify the certificate against a trusted certificate authority only without checking whether the intended host name for the certificate matches the actual host name. For example, a certificate for "www.production.com" will be accepted even if it is being used on "www.test.com". Use this option if you have a valid certificate and wish to test it in your test environment.

member.name: F:EO.Pdf.SSLVerificationMode.VerifyHost
member.summary: Verify the certificate against a trusted certificate authority, and also verify the host name for the certificate. This ensures the certificate is authentic and also ensures it is used on the intended site.

member.name: T:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf
member.summary: HTML to PDF converter.

remarks.para: Use this class to convert any Web page Url or HTML text to a PDF file, to a or to a . For example, the following code convert Google's home page to a PDF file named "google_home_page.pdf":
remarks.code: //Convert a Url to PDF file HtmlToPdf.ConvertUrl("http://www.google.com", "google_home_page.pdf");
'Convert a Url to PDF file HtmlToPdf.ConvertUrl("http://www.google.com", "google_home_page.pdf")
remarks.para: You can also configure various options through the HtmlToPdf object's property. For example, the following code set the output page size to be A3:
remarks.code:
'Set output page size HtmlToPdf.Options.PageSize = PdfPageSizes.A3
'Convert the Url HtmlToPdf.ConvertUrl("http://www.google.com", "google_home_page.pdf")
remarks.para: In addition to converting Url, you can also convert an HTML file or HTML markup directly. The following code convert HTML file "c:\hello.html" or HTML markup "Hello!" directly:
remarks.code: 'Convert a HTML file to PDF file HtmlToPdf.ConvertUrl("c:\hello.html", "hello.pdf") 'Convert HTML markup to PDF file HtmlToPdf.ConvertHtml("Hello!", "hello.pdf")
remarks.para: You can convert Url or HTML markup to a physical file or directly to an output or without creating a PDF file. See ConvertUrl and ConvertHtml for more details.

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.HtmlToPdf.UseClassicEngine
member.summary: Instructs the HTML to PDF converter to use the original browser engine used in early versions.

remarks.para: EO.Pdf 2015 and earlier uses a WebKit based browser engine, where as the current version of EO.Pdf uses a blink based browser engine, which is significantly newer. For backwards compatibiity, you can call this method to instruct the HTML to PDF converter to use the old engine.
If you call this method, you must also include EO.Pdf.Classic.dll with you distribution, otherwise you should include EO.WebEngine.dll and EO.WebBrowser.dll with your distribution.

remarks.code: //Display debug messages on the standard output stream HtmlToPdf.DebugConsole = Console.Out;
'Display debug messages on the standard output stream HtmlToPdf.DebugConsole = Console.Out
remarks.para: Once you call the above code, you can use the following JavaScript code in your page to output debug messages:
remarks.code: //Write debug message to the debug console console.log("hello! I am called!");

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.PdfDocument.Split(System.Int32[])
member.summary: Splits the current into multiple objects.
member.param: The indexes of the page where split occurs. See remark section for more details.
member.returns: An array of objects.

remarks.para: This function splits a at the specified position. For example, the following code splits the current into two objects: the first one contains the first 2 pages and the second contains all the remaining pages:
remarks.code: //Split doc from the third page PdfDocument[] docs = doc.Split(2);
'Split doc from the third page Dim docs As PdfDocument() = doc.Split(2)
remarks.para: The following code splits the current into three objects: the first one contains the first 2 pages, the second one contains the third page and the third one contains all the remaining pages.
remarks.code: //Split doc at the third page and the fourth page PdfDocument[] docs = doc.Split(2, 3);
'//Split doc at the third page and the fourth page Dim docs As PdfDocument() = doc.Split(2, 3)
remarks.para: Each "child" must contain at least one page, otherwise an error will be thrown. For example, the following code will throw an error because the first "child" would have zero pages.
remarks.code: 'This code will throw an error because the first child 'PdfDocument would have zero pages Dim docs As PdfDocument() = doc.Split(0)

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.PdfDocument.Merge(EO.Pdf.PdfDocument[])
member.summary: Merges multiple objects into a single object.
member.param: A list of objects to be merged.
member.returns: Returns a single that contains all pages from each of the supplied document.

remarks.para: If any of the source has bookmarks, the bookmarks will be merged into the result document. By default, this function appends all the root bookmark items into the result document's root bookmark item list. For example, if the first document has 3 root items and the second document has 2 root items while merging two documents, then the result document will have 5 root items.

This behavior can be changed by using placeholder bookmark items. A placeholder bookmark item is a special bookmark item that represents all bookmark items for a given document. Follow these steps to use a placeholder item:

item.code: 'Creates a placeholder representing all bookmark 'items for "doc2" Dim placeHolderForDoc2 As PdfBookmark = PdfBookmark.CreatePlaceHolder(doc2)

item.para: Insert the placeholder item into the first document's bookmark tree at where you wish the target document's bookmarks to appear. For example, the following code instructs all top level bookmark items for "doc2" to appear under the first top level bookmark item of doc1.
item.code: 'Insert all bookmarks in doc2 as child nodes of the 'first bookmark of doc1 doc1.Bookmarks(0).ChildNodes.Add(placeHolderForDoc2)

remarks.para: You can use placeholder bookmark items any of the source documents that points to any other source documents. However they cannot form a circle. For example, you cannot have doc2's top level items inserted as child items of doc1 and have doc1's top level items inserted as child items of doc2 at the same time.

member.param: Whether to automatically fix up the links between the objects to be merged. See remark section for details.

remarks.para: When using this method to merge multiple objects, it also updates the corresponding objects. The objects in the object previously point to separate objects. After the merge, they all point to locations inside the merged .

Full path of the second PDF file.
Specify on which level the second file's bookmarks should be inserted into. See remark section for more details.

remarks.para: This function appends the second PDF file to the end of the first PDF file and does not perform a "deep merge". thus can result in bigger file but uses less memory and is much faster.

If either of the source file has bookmarks, then they will be merged into the final file. In case both file has bookmarks, it may be necessary to insert the second file's bookmarks as child bookmarks of a bookmark item in the first file. For example, consider the following bookmark structure:
The first file's bookmarks:

remarks.para: The second file's bookmarks:
remarks.code: File Structure Object Types Members
remarks.para: If the desired final bookmarks is:
remarks.code: Chapter 1 - Overview Introduction Terms and definitions Chapter 2 - Syntax File Structure Object Types Members
remarks.para: Then bookmarkLevel should be set to 1, which indicating the second file's bookmarks will be on the second level (0 based).
If bookmarkLevel is set to 0, then all bookmarks for the second file will be directly appended after "Chapter 2":

member.name: M:EO.Pdf.PdfPage.Transform(EO.Pdf.Drawing.PdfMatrix)
member.summary: Transform the page contents by the specific .

remarks.para: The transformation can scale, translate, rotate, or skew page contents. For example, the following code rotates the page contents by 30 degrees clockwise:

para.code: 'Rotate page contents by 30 degrees clockwise Dim matrix As New PdfMatrix() matrix.Rotate(-30) pdfPage.Transform(matrix)

remarks.para: Please note:

item.para: PDF page Y coordinates is from bottom to top. Thus you must use a negative offset Y value to move the contents downwards. For example, the following matrix moves the page contents downwards for one inch:
item.code: //Matrix to move contents downwards for one inch matrix.Translate(0, -72);
'Matrix to move contents downwards for one inch matrix.Translate(0, -72)

item.para: Negative degrees rotate contents clockwise, positive degrees rotate contents counter clockwise. For example, the following matrix rotates the page contents 30 degrees clockwise:
item.code: //Matrix to rotate the page contents 30 degrees clockwise matrix.Rotate(-30);
'Matrix to rotate the page contents 30 degrees clockwise matrix.Rotate(-30)
item.para: The coordinate origin is the bottom left corner of the page.

remarks.para: The following code rotate the page 180 degrees:
remarks.code: Dim matrix As New PdfMatrix() matrix.Rotate(180) matrix.Translate(-612, -792) pdfPage.Transform(matrix)
remarks.para: Note that you must also call to translate the matrix sicne the coordinate origin is at the bottom left corner of the page. The exact translate amount depends on the size of the page. The above value is for page size 8.5 inch by 11 inch (612 = 8.5 * 72, 792 = 11 * 72).
